title.narrative: Sumba Iconic Island Solar Services

description.narrative: Access to alternative renewable energy is created through a bottom-up collaboration between government (national, regional and local), the state electricity company PLN, private sector enterprises (some through their Corporate Social Responsibility activities), civil society organizations, international donors and energy access projects that contribute to the Iconic Island roadmap. In addition to addressing energy access, coalition partners also promote economic opportunities for women in the community.

participating-org.narrative: Hivos Regional Office South East Asia
Lembaga Peduli Sejahtera dan Lestari (Pelita - Sumba)
Ministry of Foreign Affairs The Netherlands

receiver-org.narrative: Lembaga Peduli Sejahtera dan Lestari (Pelita - Sumba)
Lembaga Peduli Sejahtera dan Lestari (Pelita - Sumba)

title.narrative: 1. Rural off-grid users, including schools, households and individuals, invest in and apply clean energy technologies with gender-inclusiveness.
1.2f Renewable energy users (beneficiaries of RE installations) (Female in Central Sumba District, East Nusa Tenggara Province)

comment.narrative: Overall target in 4 districts: 45,500 (people) direct and indirect beneficiaries from 4 districts of Sumba

Female (registered users) direct beneficiaries (household) in Central Sumba District are 543 (unique number).
Q1: 127 Q2: 146 Q3: 66 Q4: 140 Q5: 60 Q6: 4 Q7: 0
Overall number for Sumba Island:
In total the project has reached 8,558 households received renewable energy access from lantern, paygo system and use of agroprocessing as direct beneficiaries. From the total 8,558 household, we aggregate the data based on male and female registered as lantern/Paygo/agroprocessing users (unique numbers).
Furthermore, for the indirect beneficiaries we can estimate that the number of people received renewable energy access are 52,341 people (Male: 26,389, Female: 25,952). This calculate the total number of member of household registered as users of renewable energy.
However, based on DGIS indicator methodology description v6 document, indicator of “Number of people with access to renewable energy” focuses on energy access at home i.e. number of people in households getting access. The indicator does not capture energy access for agriculture, industry and social institutions (schools, health centers). Providing access also means assisting households to acquire decentralized renewable energy systems for lighting and electric appliances (such as solar home systems).
Based on the above definition, Hivos calculates the beneficiaries of this project as household members of solar lantern users and paygo system users, and also household members of energy kiosk agents. Below is the calculation:
West Sumba District: - Number of household of solar lantern users and paygo system users: 1,889 household - Total number of people: 9,214 (Male: 4,568, Female: 4,646)
Southwest Sumba District: - Number of household of solar lantern users and paygo system users: 2,527 - Total number of people: 14,188 (Male: 7,148, Female: 7,040)
Central Sumba District: - Number of household of solar lantern users and paygo system users: 1,092 - Total number of people: 5,262 (Male: 2,627, Female: 2,635)
East Sumba District: - Number of household of solar lantern users and paygo system users: 1,864 - Total number of people: 8,700 (Male: 4,275, Female: 4,425)
Total: 7372 household OR 37,364 people (Male: 18,618, Female: 18,746)

title.narrative: 1.1d Number of RE system constructed or installed (PV Solar) in East Sumba District, East Nusa Tenggara Province

comment.narrative: In total 95 (spread in 4 districts of Sumba)

Q1. PV Schools: 5, E-Kiosk: 1 Q2. 0 Q3. E-Kiosk: 8, PV School: 2 Q4. PV Agroprocessing: 12 (corn sheller & mills) Q5. PV Agro-processing: 8 (Rice hulls) Q6. 0 Q7. E-Kios: 14, PV School: 2
Total: 52 RE system constructed or installed (PV Solar) in East Sumba District, East Nusa Tenggara Province
However, in total there are 129 RE system constructed/installed in 4 districts of Sumba Island (136% target achieved) which consists of: - 50 PV agroprocessing mills, distributing 1,081 Paygo system - 35 PV schools, distributing 4,680 solar lanterns - 44 energy kiosks, distributing 3,050 solar lanterns

title.narrative: 0. Create sustainable, commercially-oriented off-grid renewable energy solutions at affordable prices for off-grid households in Sumba
0.2 Estimated greenhouse gas emissions reduced or avoided (mt CO2e)

comment.narrative: 60.07 mt CO2e

Hivos uses different methodology from what was mentioned in the proposal when calculating the baseline of GHG Calculation. In January 2017, we assigned Castlerock Consulting Pte Ltd (Castlerock), as our external consultant to develop Greenhouse Gas Monitoring Plan for TERANG Project. Based on the document we calculated our GHG to monitor the emission reductions and the potential leakage of GHG resulted from the RE project. The baseline emission methodology is using the calculation of energy usage, which is based on the Guidelines of Greenhouse Gas Inventories, Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, 2006.
Identification of emission sources: Renewable energy system in general replaces system that uses fossil fuels or system that would have used fossil fuels as energy sources. The sources of the GHG emissions were the GHG generated from fossil fuel burning which were used or which would have been used in the absence of the renewable energy system. The basis of the GHG emission sources for TERANG project is the GHG emissions that would have been emitted in the absence of the project activities (solar PV schools, Solar PV Kiosk, and Solar powered DC agro-processing).
The GHG emission that would have been emitted would be based on the baseline emissions. Hence, the energy baseline of TERANG project is the fuel consumption of the technology in use or that would have been used in the absence of the project activity to generate the equivalent quantity of energy.
Based on the calculation, it is projected that the Solar Services for Sumba Iconic Island will reduce/avoid GHG emission of 3,370 (ton of CO2/year) or 97% of the target set the beginning of the project.

title.narrative: 0.1a Percentage increase of net attributable household income received from utilizing RE installation (vulnerable male)

comment.narrative:
We cannot define the percentage of increase based on male/female. However we calculated the increase of net attributable household income based on 2 evaluation conducted by external consultant. The first assessment was conducted by Circle Indonesia – for Final Evaluation of TERANG Project on November 2017.The second assessment was conducted on September 2018 by Resilience Development Initiative (RDI) for Gender and Entrepreneurship Analysis for Solar Services in Sumba Island.
The results are:
Increase of income in solar PV installation at Energy Kiosks:
The result from this evaluation shows that between April-October 2017, based on indepth interview with 4 Energy Kiosks (Kios Sanses, Kios Ana Lalo, Kios Yofimayu and Kios Kaleba Tana) although the additional income remained below the projection, these four kiosks showed an upward trend of actual income from month to month with intervals ranging from 2.5% to 17.5%.
Increase of income from using solar lantern at household level:
At the end user level, with people doing productive economic activities at night the use of lanterns had the potential of generating additional income. In this case, there were 17.6% (of 585 respondents) households of school lanterns users and 9.2% (of 99 respondents) households which took benefit of the energy kiosk to use the lanterns for their productive economic activities at night. Their activities included making loom-woven textile, weaving, shelling candlenuts, making snacks, running grocery stores, packing produce, sewing, and running workshops.
The presence of lanterns also affected household expenses. As many as 59.1% (N = 585) of school lantern users and 45.5% (N = 99) users of energy kiosk lanterns said that they saved fuel cost. Before they used lanterns, they used lamps using fossil energy sources (kerosene). Within 1 week they used at least 2 litres of oil (the price per litre ranged from IDR 4,500 to IDR 7,000). After they used lanterns, their kerosene consumption was reduced; they only spent 0.5 litre per week, while their expense for charging fee only ranged from IDR 1,500 to IDR 3,000 per week.

Gender Entrepreneurship Module (Buku Panduan Pelatihan bagi Fasilitator: Pengarusutamaan Gender dalam Kewirausahaan Energi Baru Terbarukan) 5. Gender Action Learning Systems (GALS) Workbook 6. Standard of Guidelines (SoG) Resco

comment.narrative: 1. Hivos video Project documentation 2. Video Most Significant Change

1. Hivos video Project documentation 2. Video Most Significant Change 3. Testimony video of PV kiosk agents PV agro-processing agents 4. Feature video of the utilization of PV school. 5. Feature video of the utilization of PV kiosk. 6. Feature video of the utilization of PV agro-processing. 7. Long version feature video of PV school, PV kiosk & PV agro-processing. 8. Feature video of gender champions' profile. 9. Video documentation of Gender Championsip event. 10. Video documentation of SII Learning Event. 11. Feature video of of the dynamics of multi-stakeholders collaboration of SII program.

comment.narrative: 1. TERANG Newsletter 2. Speed drawing (http://bit.ly/2t59vFT ) 3. Photo Book 4. Compilation of Case Studies (English and Indonesian) 5. TERANG Case Studies for Gender Championship event & SII Learning Event 6. Gender Case Studies

title.narrative: 3.1 Number of government institution assisted

comment.narrative: From March 2017 until December 2018, Hivos recorded that the project has assisted 40 government institutions (national as well sub-national level) through various trainings and facilitation of Focus Group Discussions/Stakeholders’ Forum on provision of sustainable energy access in rural/remote areas as well as on renewable energy issues.

title.narrative: 3.2 Number of stakeholders engagement meetings at national as well as local level

comment.narrative: SII National Plenary Meeting : 4 SII Local Coordination Meeting: 4

From March 2017-December 2018, the project has facilitated 10 stakeholders’ engagement meetings at national as well as local level. Below is the list of stakeholders’ engagement meetings facilitated by the project:
National level Stakeholders engagement meeting: 1. Sumba Iconic Island Steering Committee Meeting and 12th Plenary Meeting (Bali – 28-30 August 2017) 2. Sumba Iconic Island Steering Committee Meeting (Kupang, 26 July 2018) 3. Sumba Iconic Island The 13th Plenary Meeting (Bali – 24-25 October 2018)
Sub-national level Stakeholders engagement meeting: 1. Sumba Iconic Island District Coordination Meeting (Tambolaka 10-12 April 2017) 2. Sumba Iconic Island District Coordination Meeting (Waikabubak – 21-22 November 2017) 3. Sumba Iconic Island District Coordination Meeting (Waingapu 7-8 May 2018) 4. Action Plan for RUED Implementation in East Nusa Tenggara Province (27 July 2018) 5. Action Plan for RUED Implementation in East Nusa Tenggara Province (2 November 2018) 6. Regional Electricity Plan (Rencana Umum Kelistrikan Daerah – RUKD) Model Document Development (4 December 2018) 7. RUED Model Document Development (5 December 2018)

title.narrative: 3.4b Number of promotional events created to promote the implementation of RE (Investor Forum for SII)

comment.narrative:
Since March 2017 until December 2018, the project has conducted 12 promotional events to promote the implementation of RE in Sumba specifically and Indonesia in general. Below is the list of promotional event conducted during the project implementation.
National exhibitions: 1. 6th Indonesia EBTKE ConEx 2017 in conjunction with Indonesia Clean Energy Forum 2017 (Jakarta, 13-15 September 2017) 2. Learning Event TERANG (Jakarta, 24 January 2018) 3. Learning Event SII (Kupang, 27 November 2018)
Investor Forums: 1. Workshop on Financing New Renewable Energy Project in Sumba Island (Jakarta, 31 October 2018) 2. Workshop on Development Planning of Off-Grid Electricity System on Sumba Island (Jakarta, 17 December 2018)
Program socialization to 2,400 local communities: 1. Initial project consultation (Dec 2016 - Feb 2017) 2. Installation (May-October 2017) 3. Project completion (June 2017 - March 2018) 4. Renewable Energy Socialization to Students (Bogor, West Java Province, 14 August 2017) 5. Training of Trainers (ToT), Game-Based Renewable Energy Learning for School Teachers (Waingapu, East Sumba District, 29 May 2018) 6. Media Engagement (Kupang & Waingapu, 4 and 6 July 2018)
